bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, January 15, 1952

div1.p: Hench thanks Blossom Reed for the Christmas gift of two books owned and signed by her father. He thinks the librarian at the Mayo Clinic will want to put them on display. He informs her that he is returning to Cuba and hopes to work on the preservation of Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom Reed, January 15, 1952
div1.opener:
January 15, 1952
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit
Pennsylvania
My dear Mrs. Reed:
div1.p:
I cannot tell you how touched I was by your Christmas gift. It was perhaps
the most personal gift I received. I am simply thrilled to have the two
books owned by your illustrious father and signed by him so many years ago.
My family were almost as thrilled as I, especially my Yale Medical School
son.

I am going to show them to the Librarian of the Mayo Clinic and I am sure
he will want to put them on display. Each month he displays (in a carefully
locked glass cabinet) certain rarities and these two books have a distinction
which no other could possibly have. I am deeply indebted to you for your
gracious kindness.

Mary and I leave tomorrow for a medical meeting in Cuba and I shall once
more visit Camp Lazear and places so familiar to your father. Although
I am speaking at a medical meeting, I must take time out for that and I
am once more going to see some Cuban officials about preservation of your
father's little building.

I just heard yesterday from Dr. Pedro Nogueira that the Ministry of Works
has set aside a small sum to clean up the camp site and make it a park with
a bronze plaque which will have on it the names of Finlay, Reed, Lazear,
Agramonte, Carroll and Gorgas, so I understand. But since they have not
yet done anything about the little shack, I shall try to stimulate them
anew to preserve that also. This will be a quick trip and we will be home in
three weeks.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
